texts.shortText: Previously misidentified as Membranipora membranacea, which remains a valid, but European, species.

Colony consists of a flat, white, rounded, lacelike sheet growing on the fronds of kelps, especially the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima.

Examined closely, the individual zooecia are about 1 mm long, rectangular and arranges in off-set rows (like bricks in a wall). Each zooecium has a tiny knob in each corner and fine denticles along the inner surface of the wall. Lophophore white, with about 20 tentacles.
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 5-10 cm across.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to Durban, but mostly on west coast.

Commonly found on the blade of kelps, mostly the Sea bamboo Ecklonia maxima. The rounded colonies are most abundant on kelps that are growing in sheltered waters and towards the older, distal portions of the fronds. The zooecia are fed upon by the flattened, round Crazed nudibranch Corambe sp., which is also covered with a lacelike pattern that perfectly matches the bryozoan.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
Hermaphrodite. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites, but details unknown.

Easily confused with the Membranous lace bryozoan Jellyella tuberculata which forms similar rounded, white colonies, but mostly on the red alga Epymenia obtusa. The shape of the zooecia also differs, those of J. tuberculata being hexagonal, not rectangular. The Hairy lace bryozoan Electra pilosa also makes white sheets on algae, but its zooecia are elongate triangular and have one long and four short spines along the distal margin.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 11).
